recipe.title: Hoisin & Shiitake Burgers with Miso Mayonnaise & Roasted Sweet Potato Wedges
recipe.sub_title: with Miso Mayonnaise & Roasted Sweet Potato Wedges
recipe.description: Tonight, we’re combining some of our favorite Japanese and Chinese ingredients to give these burgers an exciting range of flavors. We’re packing juicy beef with potent, barbecue-like hoisin sauce and shiitake mushrooms. (Dried shiitakes offer more concentrated umami flavor—all you’ll have to do is soak them in hot water before use.) Our finishing touches are ribbons of mild tatsoi and a savory-sweet condiment of mayonnaise and white miso, a paste made from aged soybeans.

stories.title: Potato Buns
stories.description: Potato bread, a type of bread in which potato replaces a portion of the regular wheat flour, was historically associated with times of economy—when wheat became expensive during grain shortages, potato was a cheap and easy substitute. However, delicious potato bread quickly earned a permanent place on the bakery shelf. The secret is the starches in the potatoes. These dilute the gluten-forming protein of the wheat, making the resulting bread extraordinarily tender and moist—and giving it the pillowy, soft chew it’s known for. Formed into buns for sandwiches or burgers, it provides exquisite textural contrast to patties and fillings.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Scallions
stories.description: Scallions, an onion relative, belong to a class of plants with undeveloped root bulbs and long, hollow leaves. They're milder than most other onion plants and delicious both cooked and raw. (In our recipes, you'll typically cook the white bottoms and use the green tops as garnish, reflecting the difference in their potency.) Scallions are a wonderful addition to everything from scrambled eggs to soups to stir-fries.

stories.title: Sweet Potato
stories.description: Despite its name, the sweet potato is not related to the group vegetables we know as “potatoes”—rather, the sweet potato is actually a member of the morning glory family. Columbus brought the tropical root crop, native to the Americas, back to Europe after his 1492 trip to the New World. It was eagerly adopted by Europeans and given the title of “potato” (from its indigenous Taino name, “batata”). Years later, in 1537, when the white potato first arrived in Europe, locals began referring to both vegetables as “potatoes,” creating a confusion that persists today. It wasn’t until the 1740s that American colonists developed the term “sweet potato” to distinguish the delicious tuber from its white counterpart.

stories.title: Sweet White Miso Paste
stories.description: This thick, flavorful paste made from fermented soybeans and rice retains the familiarly earthy, fruity taste of white miso paste. As its name attests, though, it has a notably sweeter flavor than other miso pastes, which makes it ideal for balancing out salty and savory dishes. We love it in soups, sauces, marinades and condiments alike.

stories.title: Hoisin Sauce
stories.description: This thick, pungent sauce is a tremendously popular barbecue-like sauce used in Chinese cooking. It’s a favorite for grilling and marinades, as a dipping sauce, or an addition to stir-fries. It’s made from soybeans, garlic, and other aromatics and flavorings, and has a delicious sweet and spicy flavor.

stories.title: Dried Shiitake Mushrooms
stories.description: Shiitake mushrooms are a coveted, East Asian variety with distinctively earthy flavor. The process of sun-drying these mushrooms not only preserves them, but also intensifies their flavor. To rehydrate them for cooking, just soak them in hot water. And as a bonus, the infused water becomes another ingredient itself: it can be added to infuse the dish more deeply with umami.

recipe_steps.step_text: Place the sweet potato wedges on a sheet pan. Drizzle with olive oil and season with the salt and pepper; toss to thoroughly coat. Arrange in a single, even layer, skin sides down, and roast 24 to 26 minutes, or until browned and tender when pierced with a fork. Remove from the oven.
While the burgers cook, place the tatsoi in a medium bowl. Drizzle with olive oil and toss to coat; season with salt and pepper to taste.

While the sweet potato wedges continue to roast, in a medium pan (nonstick, if you have one), heat 2 teaspoons of oil on medium-high until hot. Add the burgers and cook 2 to 4 minutes per side for medium-rare, or until browned and cooked to your desired degree of doneness. Transfer to a plate and set aside in a warm place, leaving any browned bits (or fond) in the pan.

Add 2 teaspoons of oil to the pan of reserved fond; heat on medium until hot. Add the buns, cut sides down, and toast 1 to 2 minutes, or until lightly browned. Transfer to a work surface. Top the toasted bun bottoms with the miso mayonnaise, cooked burgers, dressed tatsoi and bun tops. Divide the finished burgers and roasted sweet potato wedges between 2 plates. Garnish the sweet potato wedges with the green top of the scallion. Enjoy!

Once the sweet potato wedges have roasted for about 10 minutes, remove the shiitake mushrooms from the bowl of hot water (discarding the water) and transfer to a cutting board. Finely chop the mushrooms and place in a large bowl. Add the ground beef, garlic, white bottom of the scallion and hoisin sauce; season with salt and pepper. Gently mix to combine. Using your hands, form the mixture into two ½-inch-thick burgers.

Preheat the oven to 475°F. Wash and dry the fresh produce. In a heatproof bowl, combine the shiitake mushrooms and 1 cup of hot water; let stand for at least 10 minutes. Halve the sweet potato lengthwise; cut each half into 3 equal-sized wedges. Peel and mince the garlic. Cut off and discard the root end of the scallion; thinly slice, separating the white bottom and green top. Cut off and discard the root end of the tatsoi; thinly slice the leaves and stems crosswise. Halve the buns. In a bowl, combine the miso paste and mayonnaise; season with salt and pepper to taste.

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

stories.title: How To: Mince Garlic
stories.description: What would cooking be without garlic? Minced garlic helps create an amazing flavor base for virtually any meal. In this short video, chef Matt Wadiak will show you how to mince garlic in no time.

stories.title: How To: Chop Scallions
stories.description: Scallions, or green onions, are one of our favorite aromatic vegetables. There are two parts of the vegetable: the white bottom and the green top. They're used a little differently in cooking—the white bottoms are similar in use to regular onions and are usually cooked; the green tops are often used raw as a garnish. In our recipes, we specify to separate them. Check out this video to see how we do it.

recipe.title: ProvenÃ§al Chicken & Potato Stew  with Aioli & Garlic Toasts
recipe.description: Olive oil, garlic and herbs are the cornerstones of Provençal cuisine, rich in both French and Italian influences. This rustic stew has it all (including a dash of classic Herbes de Provence). Hearty chicken, potatoes and chard fill out the tomato-based broth, while green olives add pops of deliciously briny flavor. On the side, we’re serving crunchy toasts rubbed with garlic. And in traditional fashion, we’re completing the stew with a simple aioli, brightened with a splash of red wine vinegar—perfect for stirring into the broth for extra richness.

stories.title: Baguette
stories.description: This long, thin, crusty and soft loaf has been a beloved staple in France for almost 100 years. The legends surrounding the baguette’s origins are numerous—some believe it descended from popular Austrian breads, while others suggest that Napoleon himself inspired the bread’s distinctive shape. Regardless, the baguette (whose name translates to “wand” or “stick”) has firmly established itself as iconic in French culture and cuisine.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Swiss Chard
stories.description: Like spinach and beets, Swiss chard is a member of the goosefoot family—a group of hardy, leafy greens that thrive in cooler weather. In fact, chard is generally harvested up until the first frost. It originated in Italy, but is most likely named for the Swiss botanist who first identified it. Unlike beets (which are cultivated for their edible roots), chard is grown for its large leaves, which can be enjoyed raw, boiled, steamed, sautéed or roasted.

stories.title: Yukon Gold Potatoes
stories.description: These thin-skinned, golden-fleshed potatoes are a relative newcomer to the agricultural market (they were developed by Canadian researchers in the 1960s), but their popularity is no surprise. They are often referred to as an “all-purpose” potato, as they are excellent in any number of preparations, including boiling, baking, roasting and frying. When cooked, they become especially creamy in texture, with a delicious, buttery flavor.

stories.title: Tomato Paste
stories.description: This concentrated ingredient is full of rich flavor. It's made by stewing fresh tomatoes down, reducing their water content and intensifying the tomatoes. Originally, making tomato paste was a way to preserve tomatoes long beyond their season, but it can do so much more! We like to use it whenever we want to add depth of flavor quickly. In many of our recipes, we'll provide instructions for how to caramelize the paste. It has a higher concentration of natural fruit sugars, which transform when heated. Try it and taste the difference!

stories.title: Castelvetrano Olives
stories.description: This Sicilian variety of olive is known for its green color and mild, clean flavor. Grown primarily in Castelvetrano, Italy, it has meaty, buttery flesh and is a favorite snacking olive. It’s harvested young and cured in a lightly salted brine, which accounts for its vivid hue.

stories.title: Red Wine Vinegar
stories.description: Like all wine vinegars, red wine vinegar is created by allowing wine to ferment, leading to the development of acetic acid. It is then aged for up to two years to mute its potent flavor. Thanks to its pleasant mellowness, red wine vinegar is a favorite for dressings and pickles. No matter how it’s used, it’s beloved for its vibrant color and subtly fruity taste.

ingredients.description: Chicken Stew Spice Blend (All-Purpose Flour, Ground Turmeric & Herbes De Provence)
ingredients.customer_facing_name: 1 1/2 Tablespoons Chicken Stew Spice Blend (All-Purpose Flour, Ground Turmeric & Herbes De Provence)
ingredients.customer_facing_ingredient_name: Tablespoons Chicken Stew Spice Blend (All-Purpose Flour, Ground Turmeric & Herbes De Provence)

recipe_steps.step_text: Add the potatoes, chard stems and ¾ of the garlic paste to the pan of chicken; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 3 minutes, or until slightly tender and fragrant. Add the spice blend and season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring frequently, 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until thoroughly combined and fragrant.

Add the chard leaves, olives, half the vinegar and 2 cups of water to the pan of chicken and vegetables, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom of the pan. Heat to boiling on high. Once boiling, reduce the heat to medium-high and simmer, stirring occasionally, 8 to 10 minutes, or until the potatoes are tender when pierced with a fork and the liquid has reduced in volume by about half. Remove from heat and season with salt and pepper to taste.

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

recipe_steps.step_text: While the stew simmers, place the baguette on a sheet pan. Drizzle with olive oil and season with salt and pepper; toss to thoroughly coat. Arrange in a single, even layer and toast in the oven 8 to 10 minutes, or until golden brown. Remove from the oven. When cool enough to handle, carefully rub the cut sides of the toasted baguette with the whole garlic clove; discard the garlic clove.

Season the chopped chicken with salt and pepper; toss to coat. In a large, high-sided pan (or pot), heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the seasoned chicken and cook, stirring occasionally, 4 to 6 minutes, or until browned. Add the tomato paste; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 3 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through and the tomato paste is dark red.

Preheat the oven to 450°F. Wash and dry the fresh produce. Small dice the potatoes. Separate the chard leaves and stems; roughly chop the leaves and thinly slice the stems. Peel the garlic. Leaving 1 garlic clove whole, mince 3 of the garlic cloves; using the flat side of your knife, smash the minced garlic cloves until they resemble a paste (or use a zester). Using the flat side of your knife, smash the olives; remove and discard the pits, then roughly chop the olives. Cut the baguette crosswise into ½-inch-thick slices. Pat the chicken dry with paper towels and chop into small pieces; place in a bowl.

stories.title: How To: Dice a Potato
stories.description: Cut large for roasting, or small for soups and stews, there’s a special trick to quickly dicing a potato. Check out the video to see how our chefs do it.

stories.title: How To: Separate Leafy Greens from the Stems
stories.description: Check out this simple trick for separating the stems and leaves of one of our favorite ingredients: kale. You won't even need a knife!

stories.title: How To: Peel Garlic
stories.description: If you're cooking with us, you're using garlic in virtually every recipe. Don't waste any more time trying to peel it! Check out the video for a quick tip.

stories.title: How To: Make Garlic Paste
stories.description: In some of our recipes, the directions say to smash the garlic cloves into a paste as opposed to mincing them. But why smash? It has to do with how garlic cloves grows. Inside each clove are tiny pockets of essential oil, the most flavorful part. If you're using the garlic raw, it’s important to smash these pockets, releasing as much of the oil as possible and giving it a chance to infuse the whole dish with flavor. Our executive chef Matt Wadiak has created a short video to show you exactly how it's done.

stories.title: How To: Take the Pits Out of Olives
stories.description: There's a quick and easy way to remove the pit from an olive (no awkward cutting involved). Watch the video to find out!

recipe_steps.step_text: While the baguette toasts, in a medium bowl, combine the mayonnaise, remaining garlic paste and remaining vinegar; season with salt and pepper to taste. Divide the finished stew between 2 bowls. Serve with the aioli and garlic toasts on the side. Enjoy!

recipe.title: Sumac-Spiced Salmon & Labneh with Freekeh, Kale & Almond Salad
recipe.description: In this vibrant recipe, our seared salmon gets a lift from the distinctive flavors of turmeric and sumac—a red spice used for centuries to add lemony brightness to Middle Eastern dishes. We’re serving the fillets over a salad of nutty freekeh and sautéed kale. A dollop of labneh (a Middle Eastern “yogurt cheese”) seasoned with fresh mint and lemon juice makes for a perfectly creamy, cooling finish.

stories.title: Freekeh
stories.description: Freekeh is an ancient Middle Eastern dish that’s made using a special technique. First, the wheat is harvested when the grains are relatively young. The whole stalk is sun-dried, then carefully set on fire, so the chaff and stalks burn off. What remains are seeds, now clean and delightfully toasted.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Curly Kale
stories.description: With its crinkly, frilly leaves, curly kale is almost as beautiful to look at as it is delicious to eat. It’s grown mainly for autumn and winter harvests, as the cool weather actually enhances the kale's inherent sweetness. Although many of our recipes call for the fibrous center rib of the kale to be removed before the leafy green is used, the rib is actually fully edible. When chopped up finely, it makes an excellent addition to soups and stocks!

stories.title: Lemon
stories.description:
Lemon, though we may take it for granted, is one of the most important ingredients in any kitchen. Its light, pure acidity provides a vivid contrast that brightens the other flavors of countless dishes.

The most common lemons, which we use in virtually all of our dishes, are Eureka lemons. They've been grown in the United States (specifically California) since the 1850s, from Sicilian seeds. This variety of lemon flowers and ripens in every season, though the majority of the harvest happens in late winter.

stories.title: Mint
stories.description: Used in cooking (and herbal remedies) since antiquity, mint adds a distinct, crisp, clean flavor to sweet or savory dishes. There are dozens of mint species—in fact, the mint family contains many other culinary herbs, the most common of which is spearmint. Because cooking diminishes mint’s flavor, it's best to add it to an unheated dish or a component of a dish, or as a garnish shortly before serving.

stories.title: Almonds
stories.description: These popular nuts are technically the hard-shelled fruit of the almond tree, which is a member of the Prunus family. This genus also includes the trees and shrubs that produce cherries, plums, peaches and other stone fruits. With origins likely in Central and Western Asia, almonds were spread by traders on the Silk Road, and by 4000 BCE, they were enjoyed in major civilizations throughout the world. The two main varieties are sweet almonds and bitter almonds: the sweet is grown for eating, while the bitter becomes almond oil, used for flavorings or liqueur.

stories.title: Medjool Dates
stories.description: A large, juicy cultivar, the Medjool date has long been prized for its delicious sweetness and chewy texture. Originally from Morocco, Medjools were reserved for royalty and their guests. They can be prepared as desserts, or served in savory dishes. In the U.S., they're primarily grown in Bard Valley, Arizona.

stories.title: Labneh Cheese
stories.description: Labneh is a rich, creamy cheese made from strained yogurt. ("Laban" is the word for strained, or "Greek," yogurt in Arabic.) Produced from goat's or cow's milk, it has a consistency between regular yogurt and cheese, and it's often used as a condiment. In Middle Eastern cuisines, it's rolled into herbed, spiced balls, topped with olive oil and served as an appetizer.

ingredients.description: Salmon Spice Blend (Ground Sumac & Ground Turmeric)
ingredients.customer_facing_name: 2 Teaspoons Salmon Spice Blend (Ground Sumac & Ground Turmeric)
ingredients.customer_facing_ingredient_name: Teaspoons Salmon Spice Blend (Ground Sumac & Ground Turmeric)

recipe_steps.step_text: While the freekeh continues to cook, in a medium pan (nonstick, if you have one), heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the garlic and almonds; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until fragrant. Add the kale and ¼ cup water; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 4 minutes, or until the kale has wilted and the water has cooked off. Transfer to a bowl and set aside in a warm place. Rinse and dry the pan.
While the kale cooks, in a bowl, combine the labneh, half the mint (roughly chopping just before adding) and the juice of 2 lemon wedges; season with salt and pepper to taste.

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

recipe_steps.step_text: While the freekeh continues to cook, place the spice blend on a plate. Pat the salmon fillets dry with paper towels; season with salt and pepper on both sides. Coat the skinless side of each seasoned fillet in the spice blend (tapping off any excess). In the pan used to cook the kale, heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the seasoned fillets, skinless sides down. Cook 2 to 3 minutes per side, or until browned and cooked to your desired degree of doneness. Transfer to a plate.

While the freekeh cooks, wash and dry the fresh produce. Peel and mince the garlic. Remove and discard the kale stems; finely chop the leaves. Using a peeler, remove the yellow rind of the lemon, avoiding the white pith; mince the rind to get 2 teaspoons of zest (or use a zester). Quarter and deseed the lemon. Pick the mint leaves off the stems; discard the stems. Pit and roughly chop the dates.

stories.description: Zest is one of the best ways to brighten up a dish. It translates the essential oils of the citrus into flavor for all kinds of meals. See how it's done here!

stories.title: How To: Quarter and Deseed a Lemon
stories.description: Lemons are indispensable to cooking. Their tart juice brightens other flavors and can tie a dish together. We’ve come up with an easy way to get the juice out of the lemon (without having to deal with the pesky seeds). Watch this short video to see how it’s done.

recipe_steps.step_text: Heat a medium pot of salted water to boiling on high. Once boiling, add the freekeh and cook 22 to 25 minutes, or until tender. Turn off the heat. Drain thoroughly and return to the pot.

stories.title: How To: Properly Salt Cooking Water
stories.description: Seasoning cooking water (whether you're cooking pasta, vegetables or anything else) is imperative to building flavor. Check out this video to see how we do it!

recipe_steps.step_text: Stir the cooked kale, lemon zest, dates and the juice of the remaining lemon wedges into the pot of cooked freekeh; season with salt and pepper to taste. Divide the finished freekeh between 2 dishes. Top with the cooked salmon fillets. Garnish with the seasoned labneh and remaining mint. Enjoy!
recipe_steps.step_title: Finish the freekeh & plate your dish:

stories.title: Labneh Cheese
stories.description: Labneh is a rich, creamy cheese made from strained yogurt. ("Laban" is the word for strained, or "Greek," yogurt in Arabic.) Produced from goat's or cow's milk, it has a consistency between regular yogurt and cheese, and it's often used as a condiment. In Middle Eastern cuisines, it's rolled into herbed, spiced balls, topped with olive oil and served as an appetizer.

stories.title: Freekeh
stories.description: Freekeh is an ancient Middle Eastern dish that’s made using a special technique. First, the wheat is harvested when the grains are relatively young. The whole stalk is sun-dried, then carefully set on fire, so the chaff and stalks burn off. What remains are seeds, now clean and delightfully toasted.

stories.title: Medjool Dates
stories.description: A large, juicy cultivar, the Medjool date has long been prized for its delicious sweetness and chewy texture. Originally from Morocco, Medjools were reserved for royalty and their guests. They can be prepared as desserts, or served in savory dishes. In the U.S., they're primarily grown in Bard Valley, Arizona.

stories.title: How To: Get Perfect Citrus Zest
stories.description: Zest is one of the best ways to brighten up a dish. It translates the essential oils of the citrus into flavor for all kinds of meals. See how it's done here!

stories.title: How To: Separate Leafy Greens from the Stems
stories.description: Check out this simple trick for separating the stems and leaves of one of our favorite ingredients: kale. You won't even need a knife!

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Curly Kale
stories.description: With its crinkly, frilly leaves, curly kale is almost as beautiful to look at as it is delicious to eat. It’s grown mainly for autumn and winter harvests, as the cool weather actually enhances the kale's inherent sweetness. Although many of our recipes call for the fibrous center rib of the kale to be removed before the leafy green is used, the rib is actually fully edible. When chopped up finely, it makes an excellent addition to soups and stocks!

stories.title: Lemon
stories.description:
Lemon, though we may take it for granted, is one of the most important ingredients in any kitchen. Its light, pure acidity provides a vivid contrast that brightens the other flavors of countless dishes.

The most common lemons, which we use in virtually all of our dishes, are Eureka lemons. They've been grown in the United States (specifically California) since the 1850s, from Sicilian seeds. This variety of lemon flowers and ripens in every season, though the majority of the harvest happens in late winter.

stories.title: Mint
stories.description: Used in cooking (and herbal remedies) since antiquity, mint adds a distinct, crisp, clean flavor to sweet or savory dishes. There are dozens of mint species—in fact, the mint family contains many other culinary herbs, the most common of which is spearmint. Because cooking diminishes mint’s flavor, it's best to add it to an unheated dish or a component of a dish, or as a garnish shortly before serving.

stories.title: Almonds
stories.description: These popular nuts are technically the hard-shelled fruit of the almond tree, which is a member of the Prunus family. This genus also includes the trees and shrubs that produce cherries, plums, peaches and other stone fruits. With origins likely in Central and Western Asia, almonds were spread by traders on the Silk Road, and by 4000 BCE, they were enjoyed in major civilizations throughout the world. The two main varieties are sweet almonds and bitter almonds: the sweet is grown for eating, while the bitter becomes almond oil, used for flavorings or liqueur.

When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. recipe.title: Mushroom & Swiss Chard Calzones with Fresh Mozzarella & Tomato Dipping Sauce
recipe.sub_title: with Fresh Mozzarella & Tomato Dipping Sauce
recipe.description: It’s Italian night, chefs! We’re filling these classic vegetarian calzones with sautéed mushrooms and Swiss chard, one of our favorite leafy greens. For plenty of rich, savory flavor and satisfying texture, we’re also using three kinds of cheese: fresh mozzarella, ricotta and Parmesan. All these golden-crusted calzones need on the side is a simple, lightly spiced tomato sauce for dipping.

stories.title: Pizza Dough
stories.description: Since its inception in 18th-Century Naples, pizza has become a global phenomenon. The base of any good pizza is a good pizza dough: typically a lean, yeast-leavened dough that bakes up to soft-on-the-inside, crispy-on-the-outside perfection in a hot pizza oven. Pizza dough has a much higher gluten content than regular bread dough, giving it enough elasticity to be stretched into a thin pie and creating a perfectly chewy bite when baked.

stories.title: Crushed Tomatoes
stories.description: Tomatoes first became popular in America during the Civil War, when the country found itself in need of foods that could be easily canned and shipped. The hardy tomato, which grew quickly and held up well in the canning process, rose to the occasion. Today, tomatoes are canned in many forms—whole, crushed, diced or as sauce or paste. Unlike canned tomato sauce, which is made by cooking tomatoes down until they become concentrated and smooth, crushed tomatoes come from fresh tomatoes that are ground, then often mixed with tomato purée before being canned. This results in a brighter, fresher flavor and chunkier texture than canned tomato sauce.

stories.title: Fresh Mozzarella
stories.description: Mozzarella is a mild cheese originally from Southern Italy. Like provolone and caciocavallo, the cheese is made using the "pasta filata" method. Milk is heated and the curds and whey are allowed to separate. The whey is then drained off, and the curds are steeped in hot water and kneaded until the cheese becomes ropy, elastic and supple. Long pieces are pulled out, cut and shaped into individual balls. The word mozzarella comes from the word mozzare, meaning "to cut," and refers to this last step in the cheese-making process. Mozzarella isn't aged, so it's best eaten fresh.

stories.title: White Mushrooms
stories.description: White mushrooms are considered one of the prime examples of the “fifth basic taste,” umami, commonly described as the “savory taste.” Renowned for their mild, earthy flavor, white mushrooms are a distinctly versatile ingredient, and can be prepared in any number of ways. Because they grow so close to the ground, it’s important to clean mushrooms before cooking them—a damp paper towel should do the trick and ensure your mushrooms are free of grit!

stories.title: Ricotta Cheese
stories.description: Ordinarily, cheese is made by adding cultures to milk, which causes the proteins in the milk to solidify into curds—these curds can then be turned into an extraordinary variety of different cheeses. As industrious cheesemakers know, though, curds are not the only source of cheesemaking potential. It turns out that whey, the flavorful liquid created as a byproduct from the creation of curds, can be used to create a delicious cheese in its own right. When heated, wholesome whey can be formed into semi-soft, creamy ricotta. Because of its mildness, ricotta makes a perfect addition to pastas, pizzas, or baked dishes both sweet and savory. (We’ve been known to enjoy it all on its own, too!)

stories.title: Parmesan Cheese
stories.description: Parmesan, or Parmigiano-Reggiano, is a hard cheese from Italy. It's named for the regions that produce it: Parma, Reggia Emilia, Bologna, Modena and Mantova. The name "Parmesan," and any translated form, is a protected designation of origin, meaning that only cheeses produced specifically in this region can be called "Parmesan." We can see why they would want to protect their name. This aged cheese has a distinct, granular texture and a unique, slightly nutty brininess that have made it one of the most popular European cheeses in the world. It's great for adding texture and flavor to pastas, but just as good shaved on top of salads (or eaten alone as a snack).

ingredients.description: Calzone Spice Blend (Aleppo Pepper & Italian Seasoning)
ingredients.customer_facing_name: 2 Teaspoons Calzone Spice Blend (Aleppo Pepper & Italian Seasoning)
ingredients.customer_facing_ingredient_name: Teaspoons Calzone Spice Blend (Aleppo Pepper & Italian Seasoning)

recipe_steps.step_text: Preheat the oven to 475°F. Wash and dry the fresh produce. Remove the dough from the refrigerator to bring to room temperature. Thinly slice the mushrooms. Separate the chard leaves and stems; finely chop the leaves and thinly slice the stems. Peel and mince the garlic. Tear the mozzarella cheese into small pieces.

stories.title: How To: Mince Garlic
stories.description: What would cooking be without garlic? Minced garlic helps create an amazing flavor base for virtually any meal. In this short video, chef Matt Wadiak will show you how to mince garlic in no time.

stories.title: How To: Separate Leafy Greens from the Stems
stories.description: Check out this simple trick for separating the stems and leaves of one of our favorite ingredients: kale. You won't even need a knife!

recipe_steps.step_text: Sprinkle a big pinch of the flour onto a clean, dry work surface. Divide the dough into 3 equal-sized portions. Using your hands, gently stretch the portions into ¼-inch-thick rounds. (If the dough is resistant, let rest for 5 minutes.) Divide the filling between the centers of the rounds; fold each round in half over the filling. Using your fingers or a fork, press or crimp the edges of the dough to seal the calzones.
To the bowl of cooked vegetables, add the ricotta cheese, Parmesan cheese, mozzarella cheese and â…“ of the tomato sauce. Stir to thoroughly combine; season with salt and pepper to taste.

Sprinkle the remaining flour on a sheet pan. Carefully transfer the calzones to the prepared sheet pan; drizzle or brush the tops with olive oil. Bake 16 to 18 minutes, or until golden brown. Remove from the oven and let stand for at least 2 minutes. Serve with the remaining tomato sauce on the side. Enjoy!
recipe_steps.step_title: Bake the calzones & serve your dish:

recipe_steps.step_text: In a medium pan (nonstick, if you have one), heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the mushrooms and cook, stirring occasionally, 4 to 6 minutes, or until browned and softened. Add the chard leaves and stems; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 4 minutes, or until the leaves have wilted and the stems are tender. Transfer to a large bowl.

While the vegetables cook, in a small pot, heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the garlic; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring frequently, 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until fragrant. Add the spice blend and cook, stirring frequently, 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until toasted and fragrant. Add the crushed tomatoes and simmer, stirring occasionally, 3 to 5 minutes, or until slightly reduced in volume. Remove from heat and season with salt and pepper to taste.

stories.title: How to Know When Your Spices Are Toasted
stories.description: Toasting spices is an easy way to develop and deepen their flavors. What makes spices interesting and distinct are the unique essential oils they contain. Heating the spices activates these oils, transforming them into something so much more. You'll notice the difference in your finished dish. To know when your spices are toasted, trust your senses! They're ready to go when your kitchen fills with a delightful, comforting aroma.

The base of any good pizza is a good pizza dough: typically a lean, yeast-leavened dough that bakes up to soft-on-the-inside, crispy-on-the-outside perfection in a hot pizza oven. Pizza dough has a much higher gluten content than regular bread dough, giving it enough elasticity to be stretched into a thin pie and creating a perfectly chewy bite when baked.

stories.title: Semolina Flour
stories.description: Semolina flour is a coarse, purified product made from durum wheat. (Durum flour is actually finely ground semolina.) It's most commonly used to make pastas, couscous and breakfast cereals. But in some parts of the world—particularly Eastern Europe, South Asia and North and West Africa—semolina flour is also boiled into soups and porridges (similar to the way ground corn is boiled to make grits). It can also be whipped into puddings and other sweet desserts.

stories.description: Like spinach and beets, Swiss chard is a member of the goosefoot family—a group of hardy, leafy greens that thrive in cooler weather. In fact, chard is generally harvested up until the first frost. It originated in Italy, but is most likely named for the Swiss botanist who first identified it. Unlike beets (which are cultivated for their edible roots), chard is grown for its large leaves, which can be enjoyed raw, boiled, steamed, sautéed or roasted.

We can see why they would want to protect their name. recipe.title: English Pea & Goat Cheese Quiches with Pea Shoot & Shaved Parmesan Salad
recipe.sub_title: with Pea Shoot & Shaved Parmesan Salad
recipe.description: There’s nothing more emblematic of spring than sweet, fresh peas. This gourmet recipe uses the crop in two ways: we’re baking peas (alongside chard) into our light, creamy quiches, which we’re pairing with a quick salad of pea shoots. This delectable, seasonal ingredient­—the leaves and tendrils of the plant­—needs only a splash of lemon vinaigrette to shine. But for extra flavor, we’re also adding sharp, shaved Parmesan.

stories.title: Pie Crust
stories.description: As any baker will tell you, the key to the perfect quiche or savory tart is the perfect pie crust. The deceptively simple-looking pie crust generally starts with flour, salt and sometimes sugar, to which butter or shortening is added. Although pie crusts can vary in size and exact ingredient proportions, all great pie crusts share the same flaky texture and deliciously buttery flavor.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Pea Shoots
stories.description: Pea shoots can refer to the first growth leaves of many different varieties of pea plant. They can be used raw as a salad green or cooked into dishes like a leafy green. These delicate leaves are the taste of spring itself.

stories.title: Lemon
stories.description:
Lemon, though we may take it for granted, is one of the most important ingredients in any kitchen. Its light, pure acidity provides a vivid contrast that brightens the other flavors of countless dishes.

The most common lemons, which we use in virtually all of our dishes, are Eureka lemons. They've been grown in the United States (specifically California) since the 1850s, from Sicilian seeds. This variety of lemon flowers and ripens in every season, though the majority of the harvest happens in late winter.

stories.title: Swiss Chard
stories.description: Like spinach and beets, Swiss chard is a member of the goosefoot family—a group of hardy, leafy greens that thrive in cooler weather. In fact, chard is generally harvested up until the first frost. It originated in Italy, but is most likely named for the Swiss botanist who first identified it. Unlike beets (which are cultivated for their edible roots), chard is grown for its large leaves, which can be enjoyed raw, boiled, steamed, sautéed or roasted.

stories.title: Shallot
stories.description: Shallots are an intensely flavorful bulb in the same family as garlic and leeks. Many of the vegetables in this family are considered aromatics. Garlic, shallots, leeks, onions and many other fragrant vegetables are called aromatics because of the amazing scents they produce during cooking. Almost every cuisine uses some combination of these vegetables as a base. Aromatics build flavor, providing structure and a subtle, well-rounded backdrop for the “stars” of your dish.

stories.title: English Peas
stories.description: Technically a kind of legume (like beans or lentils), peas are native to Western Asia. They’ve been cultivated since the Bronze Age. They spread to India and China by the 7th Century. (In Chinese, the word for pea translates to “foreign legume.”) During that time, peas (also called “field peas”) were quickly becoming a staple of European Medieval cuisine. These cuisines featured almost exclusively the pea itself (the seed of the plant). They’re still delicious and another sign that spring has sprung!

stories.title: Sour Cream
stories.description: Sour cream is formed, much like yogurt, by adding natural cultures to regular cream and allowing the product to thicken and acquire its characteristic tang. Originally extremely popular in Central and Eastern Europe, immigrants brought an insatiable taste for it to the United States. By the middle of the 20th Century it had earned a prominent place in American cooking, as a base for dips or dressings, a secret ingredient in cakes and baked goods and, of course, as the perfect topping for baked potatoes. Because of its high protein content, cooking it at hot temperatures can cause sour cream to curdle, so it is best added to the colder components of a dish, used as a garnish, or mixed in to a dish right before serving.

stories.title: Goat Cheese
stories.description: Cheese made from goat’s milk has a distinctly earthy, tart flavor that sets it apart from cheeses made from cow’s milk. Because goats were among the first domesticated animals, goat cheese was likely among the world’s original forms of cheese; it has been enjoyed for thousands of years and was a particular favorite of the Ancient Greeks. Today, it remains a beloved staple in Mediterranean, Middle Eastern and North American diets, and it’s prized for its soft, crumbly and creamy texture.

stories.title: Parmesan Cheese
stories.description: Parmesan, or Parmigiano-Reggiano, is a hard cheese from Italy. It's named for the regions that produce it: Parma, Reggia Emilia, Bologna, Modena and Mantova. The name "Parmesan," and any translated form, is a protected designation of origin, meaning that only cheeses produced specifically in this region can be called "Parmesan." We can see why they would want to protect their name. This aged cheese has a distinct, granular texture and a unique, slightly nutty brininess that have made it one of the most popular European cheeses in the world. It's great for adding texture and flavor to pastas, but just as good shaved on top of salads (or eaten alone as a snack).

recipe_steps.step_text: While the vegetables cook, season the shallot-lemon juice mixture with salt and pepper to taste. Slowly whisk in 2 tablespoons of olive oil until well combined. Set aside. Crack the eggs into a large bowl; season with salt and pepper and beat until smooth. Whisk in the sour cream and 2 tablespoons of water until smooth. Add the blanched peas and cooked chard; season with salt and pepper and whisk until thoroughly combined.

stories.title: How to Build Any Vinaigrette
stories.description: With dressings, as with most things, we believe simpler is better! There are three basic components of a vinaigrette: a base, some kind of seasoning and oil. As the name suggests, the base of a vinaigrette is commonly vinegar, but any other acidic ingredient will work just as well (we love using fresh lemon juice). Next: the seasoning. In many of our recipes, we use salt and pepper. It's important to season the base before adding the oil. Salt is water soluble and will dissolve well into vinegar or lemon juice. (It won't dissolve into oil.) From there, all you have to do is add the oil. Add it in a slow, steady stream and whisk constantly to emulsify (or incorporate) the vinaigrette. Simply add it to the salad and toss to coat.

recipe_steps.step_text: Add the peas to the pot of boiling water and cook 2 to 4 minutes, or until bright green and tender. Turn off the heat. Drain the peas thoroughly and rinse under cold water to stop the cooking process; transfer to a bowl. Rinse and dry the pot.

In the pot used to blanch the peas, heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the garlic and chard stems; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 1 to 2 minutes, or until lightly browned and fragrant. Add the chard leaves; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 3 minutes, or until the chard leaves have wilted. Remove from heat.

Just before serving, in a large bowl, combine the pea shoots and Parmesan cheese; season with salt and pepper. Add enough of the vinaigrette to coat the salad (you may have extra); toss to combine. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Serve the baked quiches with the salad on the side. Enjoy!
recipe_steps.step_title: Make the salad & serve your dish:

stories.title: How To: Dress a Salad
stories.description: A properly dressed salad allows the delicate flavors of the greens to shine through. In this video, we'll give you a few quick tips to take your salads to the next level.

recipe_steps.step_text: Place the pie crusts on a sheet pan, leaving them in their tins. Divide the filling between the crusts (you may have extra filling) and top with the goat cheese; season with salt and pepper. Bake 18 to 20 minutes, or until the crusts have browned and the filling is cooked through and slightly crispy on top. Remove from the oven and let stand for at least 5 minutes before serving.

Preheat the oven to 425°F. Wash and dry the fresh produce. Heat a small pot of salted water to boiling on high. Shell the peas. Peel and mince the garlic. Separate the chard leaves and stems; roughly chop the leaves and thinly slice the stems, keeping them separate. Quarter and deseed the lemon. Peel and mince the shallot to get 2 tablespoons of minced shallot (you may have extra); place in a bowl with the juice of all 4 lemon wedges.

stories.title: How To: Mince Garlic
stories.description: What would cooking be without garlic? Minced garlic helps create an amazing flavor base for virtually any meal. In this short video, chef Matt Wadiak will show you how to mince garlic in no time.

stories.title: How To: Quarter and Deseed a Lemon
stories.description: Lemons are indispensable to cooking. Their tart juice brightens other flavors and can tie a dish together. We’ve come up with an easy way to get the juice out of the lemon (without having to deal with the pesky seeds). Watch this short video to see how it’s done.

stories.title: How To: Separate Leafy Greens from the Stems
stories.description: Check out this simple trick for separating the stems and leaves of one of our favorite ingredients: kale. You won't even need a knife!

stories.title: How To: Take the Bite out of Shallots
stories.description: Placing minced shallot in a bowl of vinegar works wonders. It mellows the shallot, removing its pungent bite while accenting its robust flavor. Check out this article on our blog to find out exactly why.

stories.title: How To: Properly Salt Cooking Water
stories.description: Seasoning cooking water (whether you're cooking pasta, vegetables or anything else) is imperative to building flavor. Check out this video to see how we do it!

stories.title: Pea Shoots
stories.description: Pea shoots can refer to the first growth leaves of many different varieties of pea plant. They can be used raw as a salad green or cooked into dishes like a leafy green. These delicate leaves are the taste of spring itself.

stories.title: English Peas
stories.description: Technically a kind of legume (like beans or lentils), peas are native to Western Asia. They’ve been cultivated since the Bronze Age. They spread to India and China by the 7th Century. (In Chinese, the word for pea translates to “foreign legume.”) During that time, peas (also called “field peas”) were quickly becoming a staple of European Medieval cuisine. These cuisines featured almost exclusively the pea itself (the seed of the plant). They’re still delicious and another sign that spring has sprung!

stories.title: Pie Crust
stories.description: As any baker will tell you, the key to the perfect quiche or savory tart is the perfect pie crust. The deceptively simple-looking pie crust generally starts with flour, salt and sometimes sugar, to which butter or shortening is added. Although pie crusts can vary in size and exact ingredient proportions, all great pie crusts share the same flaky texture and deliciously buttery flavor.

stories.title: Goat Cheese
stories.description: Cheese made from goat’s milk has a distinctly earthy, tart flavor that sets it apart from cheeses made from cow’s milk. Because goats were among the first domesticated animals, goat cheese was likely among the world’s original forms of cheese; it has been enjoyed for thousands of years and was a particular favorite of the Ancient Greeks. Today, it remains a beloved staple in Mediterranean, Middle Eastern and North American diets, and it’s prized for its soft, crumbly and creamy texture.

stories.title: How To: Take the Bite out of Shallots
stories.description: Placing minced shallot in a bowl of vinegar works wonders. It mellows the shallot, removing its pungent bite while accenting its robust flavor. Check out this article on our blog to find out exactly why.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Swiss Chard
stories.description: Like spinach and beets, Swiss chard is a member of the goosefoot family—a group of hardy, leafy greens that thrive in cooler weather. In fact, chard is generally harvested up until the first frost. It originated in Italy, but is most likely named for the Swiss botanist who first identified it. Unlike beets (which are cultivated for their edible roots), chard is grown for its large leaves, which can be enjoyed raw, boiled, steamed, sautéed or roasted.

stories.title: Lemon
stories.description:
Lemon, though we may take it for granted, is one of the most important ingredients in any kitchen. Its light, pure acidity provides a vivid contrast that brightens the other flavors of countless dishes.

The most common lemons, which we use in virtually all of our dishes, are Eureka lemons. They've been grown in the United States (specifically California) since the 1850s, from Sicilian seeds. This variety of lemon flowers and ripens in every season, though the majority of the harvest happens in late winter.

stories.title: Shallot
stories.description: Shallots are an intensely flavorful bulb in the same family as garlic and leeks. Many of the vegetables in this family are considered aromatics. Garlic, shallots, leeks, onions and many other fragrant vegetables are called aromatics because of the amazing scents they produce during cooking. Almost every cuisine uses some combination of these vegetables as a base. Aromatics build flavor, providing structure and a subtle, well-rounded backdrop for the “stars” of your dish.

stories.title: Sour Cream
stories.description: Sour cream is formed, much like yogurt, by adding natural cultures to regular cream and allowing the product to thicken and acquire its characteristic tang. Originally extremely popular in Central and Eastern Europe, immigrants brought an insatiable taste for it to the United States. By the middle of the 20th Century it had earned a prominent place in American cooking, as a base for dips or dressings, a secret ingredient in cakes and baked goods and, of course, as the perfect topping for baked potatoes. Because of its high protein content, cooking it at hot temperatures can cause sour cream to curdle, so it is best added to the colder components of a dish, used as a garnish, or mixed in to a dish right before serving.

stories.title: Parmesan Cheese
stories.description: Parmesan, or Parmigiano-Reggiano, is a hard cheese from Italy. It's named for the regions that produce it: Parma, Reggia Emilia, Bologna, Modena and Mantova. The name "Parmesan," and any translated form, is a protected designation of origin, meaning that only cheeses produced specifically in this region can be called "Parmesan." We can see why they would want to protect their name. This aged cheese has a distinct, granular texture and a unique, slightly nutty brininess that have made it one of the most popular European cheeses in the world. It's great for adding texture and flavor to pastas, but just as good shaved on top of salads (or eaten alone as a snack).

stories.title: How to Build Any Vinaigrette
stories.description: With dressings, as with most things, we believe simpler is better! There are three basic components of a vinaigrette: a base, some kind of seasoning and oil. As the name suggests, the base of a vinaigrette is commonly vinegar, but any other acidic ingredient will work just as well (we love using fresh lemon juice). Next: the seasoning. In many of our recipes, we use salt and pepper. It's important to season the base before adding the oil. Salt is water soluble and will dissolve well into vinegar or lemon juice. (It won't dissolve into oil.) From there, all you have to do is add the oil. Add it in a slow, steady stream and whisk constantly to emulsify (or incorporate) the vinaigrette. Simply add it to the salad and toss to coat.

stories.title: How To: Dress a Salad
stories.description: A properly dressed salad allows the delicate flavors of the greens to shine through. In this video, we'll give you a few quick tips to take your salads to the next level.

recipe.title: Lentil & Fennel Minestra  with Asparagus Tempura & Lemon Aioli
recipe.description: A classic vegetable soup (and minestrone’s culinary ancestor), minestra is delicious, rustic Italian fare. In this recipe, we’re using anise-like fennel and delicate French green lentils, stewed to perfection with warm spices. For an exciting, springtime take on the dish, we’re tempura-frying seasonal asparagus (or coating the stalks in rice flour batter and lightly frying them in a pan) and serving it atop the stew as a crispy, crunchy garnish.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Asparagus
stories.description:
Asparagus is actually the young shoot of a small shrub, harvested before its flesh becomes woody. The spade-shaped “leaves” that line its long, narrow body are, in fact, early branches, preparing to reach out of a soon-to-be tree trunk. Once classified as part of the lily family, like garlic and onions, asparagus and its wild cousins now belong to their own separate family, which contains over 100 unique genera (some of which are evergreen).

In Turkish, the name for asparagus is “kuÅŸkonmaz,” which literally translates to “bird can’t land.” That’s a decent description of the vegetable’s shape, but what it leaves out is asparagus’ exquisite tenderness.

stories.title: Lemon
stories.description:
Lemon, though we may take it for granted, is one of the most important ingredients in any kitchen. Its light, pure acidity provides a vivid contrast that brightens the other flavors of countless dishes.

The most common lemons, which we use in virtually all of our dishes, are Eureka lemons. They've been grown in the United States (specifically California) since the 1850s, from Sicilian seeds. This variety of lemon flowers and ripens in every season, though the majority of the harvest happens in late winter.

stories.title: Yellow Onion
stories.description: This unassuming Allium likely originated in Central Asia or the Middle East and has been cultivated for at least 5,000 years. The Egyptians thought the onion symbolized eternal life—frequently, Egyptian priests are depicted holding onions in art from the time. For many ancient civilizations, like those of China, India, Greece and Rome, onions were considered to have medicinal properties. To help improve their performance before Olympic competition, Ancient Greek athletes consumed onions by the pound. Today, we use yellow onions—considered the universal, all-purpose onion—for their robust layers and spicy, sharp and sweet flavor profile.

stories.title: Tomato Paste
stories.description: This concentrated ingredient is full of rich flavor. It's made by stewing fresh tomatoes down, reducing their water content and intensifying the tomatoes. Originally, making tomato paste was a way to preserve tomatoes long beyond their season, but it can do so much more! We like to use it whenever we want to add depth of flavor quickly. In many of our recipes, we'll provide instructions for how to caramelize the paste. It has a higher concentration of natural fruit sugars, which transform when heated. Try it and taste the difference!

ingredients.description: Lentil Minestra Spice Blend (Ground Coriander, Sweet Paprika & Garlic Powder)
ingredients.customer_facing_name: 2 Teaspoons Lentil Minestra Spice Blend (Ground Coriander, Sweet Paprika & Garlic Powder)
ingredients.customer_facing_ingredient_name: Teaspoons Lentil Minestra Spice Blend (Ground Coriander, Sweet Paprika & Garlic Powder)

recipe_steps.step_text: While the lentils simmer, in a bowl, combine the mayonnaise, remaining garlic paste and the juice of 2 lemon wedges; season with salt and pepper to taste.

Wash and dry the fresh produce. Cut off and discard any fennel stems; small dice the bulb. Peel and small dice the onion. Peel and mince the garlic; using the flat side of your knife smash until it resembles a paste (or use a zester). Quarter and deseed the lemon. Snap off and discard the rough, woody ends of the asparagus. Cut off and reserve the top 3 inches of each asparagus stalk; thinly slice the remaining stalks crosswise. Cut the chives into ½-inch pieces.

stories.title: How To: Make Garlic Paste
stories.description: In some of our recipes, the directions say to smash the garlic cloves into a paste as opposed to mincing them. But why smash? It has to do with how garlic cloves grows. Inside each clove are tiny pockets of essential oil, the most flavorful part. If you're using the garlic raw, it’s important to smash these pockets, releasing as much of the oil as possible and giving it a chance to infuse the whole dish with flavor. Our executive chef Matt Wadiak has created a short video to show you exactly how it's done.

stories.title: How To: Small Dice an Onion
stories.description: Small dice an onion? No sweat (but maybe a few tears). Check out this video to see exactly how it's done.

stories.title: How To: Quarter and Deseed a Lemon
stories.description: Lemons are indispensable to cooking. Their tart juice brightens other flavors and can tie a dish together. We’ve come up with an easy way to get the juice out of the lemon (without having to deal with the pesky seeds). Watch this short video to see how it’s done.

recipe_steps.step_text: Add the lentils and 4 cups of water to the pot; season with salt and pepper. Heat to boiling on high. Reduce the heat to medium-high; simmer, stirring occasionally, 24 to 26 minutes, or until thickened and the lentils are tender. Stir in the sliced asparagus and the juice of the remaining lemon wedges. Turn off the heat; season with salt and pepper to taste. Let stand for 2 minutes.

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

recipe_steps.step_text: While the lentils continue to simmer, in a large bowl, whisk together the rice flour and 5 tablespoons of water to create a thin batter; season with salt and pepper. In a medium pan (nonstick, if you have one), heat a thin layer of oil on medium-high until hot. Working in batches, coat the asparagus tops in the batter (letting any excess drip off). Once the oil is hot enough that a drop of batter sizzles immediately when added to the pan, carefully add the coated asparagus. Cook, flipping halfway through, 3 to 5 minutes, or until golden and crispy. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate; immediately season with salt and pepper.

stories.title: How To: Tempura Fry
stories.description: Check out this short video with some tips on how to get the perfect crust when frying tempura-style.

recipe_steps.step_text: In a large pot, heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the fennel, onion, spice blend and ¾ of the garlic paste; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 3 to 5 minutes, or until softened and fragrant. Add the tomato paste and cook, stirring frequently, 2 to 3 minutes, or until dark red and fragrant.
Divide the finished minestra between 2 bowls. Top with the asparagus tempura. Garnish with the chives. Serve with the aioli on the side. Enjoy!

stories.title: How To: Tempura Fry
stories.description: Check out this short video with some tips on how to get the perfect crust when frying tempura-style.

stories.title: French Green Lentils
stories.description: French green lentils—also known and lentilles du Puy, for the region of France where they originated—are renowned for their coveted flavor, which is delicate, peppery and earthy. With a firmer texture than regular lentils and an exquisite taste, they have been lovingly referred to as “the poor man’s caviar," and make an excellent addition to salads or soups.

stories.title: Fennel
stories.description: Fennel is one of autumn's most delicious vegetables. Crisp and fresh, with an almost licorice-y flavor, it's wonderful raw or cooked. Fennel belongs to the umbellifer family (consisting of plants with hollow stems). Its use predates the advent of written history. In fact, it was in a fennel stem that Prometheus was said to have hidden the fire he stole from the gods, lifting the human race out of darkness (and providing them with the instrument of cooking).

stories.title: Rice Flour
stories.description: This ingredient is exactly what it sounds like: finely milled rice. Most often, we're coating fish or tofu with it, then quickly searing the coated ingredient in a hot pan. Coating the protein in rice flour (a technique called dredging) does a lot for the cooking process as well as the finished dish. The flour absorbs some of the surface moisture, so it doesn’t spatter as much when being cooked. Even better, the rice flour will crisp up into a thin crust, a golden brown layer of delicious toasted rice. It’s a simple way to give all kinds of dishes a special, gourmet twist.

stories.title: Chives
stories.description: Chives belong to the allium family, a robust genus of plants (including onions, garlic, leeks and scallions) that feature in nearly every cuisine around the world. Like onions, chives are bulb plants; however, chives are cultivated for their stalks—the slender, cylindrical, hollow leaves that sprout from the bulbs—which have a delicious, mildly oniony flavor. These stalks make an excellent garnish for vegetables, salads, meats, soups or even eggs.
